results.title: In Iraqi Elections, Guns and Money Still Dominate Politics
results.abstract: Iraqis vote Sunday in parliamentary elections called a year early, after huge anti-government protests. Most parties are appealing to voters on the basis of religious, ethnic or tribal loyalty.

results.abstract: The 5.9-magnitude quake struck Thursday morning while most people were asleep, and officials feared the toll may rise.
results.byline: By Salman Masood and Azi Paybarah

results.title: Two Teachers Are Killed in Kashmir, Where Militant Attacks Are Surging
results.abstract: The killings on Thursday were the latest in a series of attacks largely targeting Hindu and Sikh civilians in Kashmir, where tensions are high after India revoked the region’s autonomy two years ago.

results.title: A ‘Historic Event’: First Malaria Vaccine Approved by W.H.O.
results.abstract: Malaria kills about 500,000 people each year, about half of them children in Africa. The new vaccine isn’t perfect, but it will help turn the tide, experts said.

results.title: Vatican Issues Acquittals in Sexual Abuse Case Involving Former Altar Boys
results.abstract: One defendant, now a priest, had been accused of sexual abuse when he and his accuser were teenage students at a seminary within the Vatican walls. Another priest was accused of covering it up.

results.title: The Afghan War: A Photographer’s Journal
results.abstract: One of the first things the New York Times photographer Tyler Hicks witnessed after arriving in Afghanistan in late 2001, soon after U.S. airstrikes on Oct. 7 opened the invasion, was the execution of a wounded Taliban fighter. The scene shocked him, upending everything he thought he knew about war and about the Afghan Northern Alliance — the U.S.-aligned fighters who had been his guides and protectors, and the Talib’s killers.
results.byline: By Tyler Hicks and David Zucchino

results.title: A New Vaccine Strategy for Children: Just One Dose, for Now

results.title: Australia to Shift All Offshore Processing of Migrants to Island Nation of Nauru
results.abstract: Australia will stop processing asylum-seekers at offshore detention centers in Papua New Guinea, which have been criticized by human rights groups, but will continue handling them on the island of Nauru.

multimedia.caption: One of the processing centers in Papua New Guinea, on Los Negros Island, that will close by the end of the year.
multimedia.copyright: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times

results.title: The White House says it will spend $1 billion to increase the supply of rapid at-home tests.
results.abstract: Tests producing results in 15 minutes have been on the market for months, but they have been in short supply in the United States.

multimedia.caption: Just one QuickVue At-Home Covid-19 test by Quidel remained in stock at a drugstore in Chicago last month.
